rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 7:2
rsbNotes.text:
7:2 the House of the Forest of Lebanon. Probably so named because of the extensive use of Lebanon cedar inside. This complex was probably located immediately south of the temple.

length . . . a hundred cubits and its breadth fifty . . . and its height thirty. Although the same height as the temple, Solomon’s palace was considerably longer and more than twice as wide (6:2).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 7:6
rsbNotes.text: 7:6 the Hall of Pillars. Half the length of the palace and about two-thirds of the width (7:2), this colonnade was probably an impressive entrance hall.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 7:7
rsbNotes.text: 7:7 the Hall of Judgment. The place where Solomon formally carried out his duties as administrator of God’s holy kingdom (3:16 note).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 7:13–51
rsbNotes.text: 7:13–51 This part of the account is not placed chronologically; Solomon actually began making arrangements for equipping the temple prior to its actual completion (2 Chr. 2:7, 13, 14).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 7:13
rsbNotes.text: 7:13 Hiram. He should not be confused with Hiram, the king of Tyre, with whom Solomon ratified a treaty for the supply of materials and craftsmen (5:1–12).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 7:15
rsbNotes.text: 7:15 two pillars of bronze. One pillar was on each side of the temple’s entrance (v. 21). It is unclear whether they were freestanding or whether they supported a roof which may have also covered the porch of the temple.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 7:16
rsbNotes.text: 7:16 two capitals. It was common in the ancient Near East to lavish capitals with ornate decoration.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 7:23
rsbNotes.text: 7:23 the sea of cast metal. A huge circular basin holding up to eight thousand gallons of water (2 Chr. 4:5 note). According to Chronicles, the priests used the Sea for cleansing (2 Chr. 4:6). Its symbolic significance is disputed. Some scholars highlight the positive attributes of water as life-giving, while others argue that the bronze Sea commemorates God’s power over the forces of chaos, typified by the sea (cf. Rev. 21:1).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 7:25
rsbNotes.text: 7:25 twelve oxen. The Sea rested on four triads of oxen pointed in the four cardinal directions. In the ancient Near East, oxen symbolized physical and reproductive potency. Their arrangement is indicative of God’s universal lordship.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 7:27
rsbNotes.text: 7:27 ten stands of bronze. These portable and highly decorated wagons held water basins (v. 38). The priests used the water to wash sections of animals that had been slaughtered for burnt offerings (Lev. 1:9, 13; 2 Chr. 4:6).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 7:40
rsbNotes.text: 7:40 shovels, and the basins. Priests used the shovels to remove ashes from the altar, and the bowls for rituals involving blood or water (Ex. 27:3; Jer. 52:18).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 7:46
rsbNotes.text: 7:46 Succoth. This center of metallurgy was located east of the Jordan, north of the Wadi Jabbok (Gen. 33:17; Josh. 13:27; Judg. 8:4, 5). Zarethan was nearby.

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 7:48
rsbNotes.text: 7:48 the golden altar . . . table. The same altar described in 6:22. The “bread of the Presence” or holy bread (1 Sam. 21:4, 6) arranged on the golden table was understood as an offering before God (Ex. 25:23–30; Lev. 24:5–9; Num. 4:7; 2 Chr. 13:11; Matt. 12:4).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 7:49
rsbNotes.text: 7:49 lampstands. There were ten lampstands in the temple, as compared to only one in the tabernacle (Ex. 25:31–40; 26:35).

rsbNotes.title: 1 Kings 7:51
rsbNotes.text:
7:51 David his father. During his reign David accumulated booty from military campaigns and received tribute from a variety of states (2 Sam. 8:9–12; 1 Chr. 18:7–11; 2 Chr. 5:1).

treasuries of the house of the Lord. Depositories for the government’s wealth, sometimes used as tribute by the kings to ward off foreign invaders (15:18; 2 Kin. 12:18; 18:13–16). The treasure was also the object of raids by opposing kings (14:25, 26; 2 Kin. 14:13, 14).
